snippet.title: Multiple bidders flock to two-storey classics - realestate.com.au
snippet.content:
sold for $1.6 million.
SEVEN bidders battled to call this neat two-storey South Melbourne terrace their own, pushing the sale price $500,000 past its reserve. Advantage Property Consulting director Frank Valentic said 6 Clarendon Place sold under the hammer for $1.6 million. "It went off life a firecracker," he said. Meanwhile, a 1970s townhouse at 55 Nicholson St, South Yarra, was knocked down for almost $350,000 more than its reserve. Read on for auction results from all sides of Melbourne. NORTH
was snapped up by a local buyer for $2 million.
SOLD FOR $2 million This modern two-storey family home set on a 334sq m block attracted one local bidder yesterday. It was passed in but negotiated to a sale. Barry Plant, Moonee Valley, auctioneer Bill Karp said the four-bedroom, two-bathroom house with a media room and heated outdoor entertainment area "deserved" $2 million. SOUTH
sold for $1.6 million.
SOLD FOR $1.6 million "It went off like a firecracker" was how Advantage Property Consulting director Frank Valentic described the battle for this two-bedroom two-storey brick terrace. Mr Valentic said it sold for 45 per cent more than its reserve of $1.1 million. An older man who could be downsizing won the keys, he said. Mr Valentic said the vendors bought it in the late 1990s for $300,000. EAST
attracted four bidders.
SOLD FOR $1.799 million This 1970s four-bedroom townhouse attracted strong competition from four bidders. Jellis Craig, South Yarra, auctioneer Andrew MacMillian said it sold under the hammer for $349,000 more than its reserve. He said a young couple with plans to renovate and live in it won the keys. Mr MacMillan said the result was a testament to the South Yarra market and a growing appreciation for the style of architecture. WEST
sold well above reserve.
SOLD FOR $1.675 million Two bidders battled it out for this multi-level home close to the beach. Hocking Stuart, Altona, agent Anthony Anile said the four-bedroom, two-bathroom house sold "well above" the reserve. "It sold for more than we thought," he said. Mr Anile said expats who were living in the UK but were returning won the keys.
